<Summary source="https://tipswatch.com/">
# Summary of Article: Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (February 16, 2026)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**30-Year TIPS Auction Details:**
- Treasury offering $9 billion in new 30-year TIPS on Thursday (February 20, 2026)
- CUSIP: 912810 US 5
- Expected real yield: possibly close to 2.5%
- Current Treasury estimate: 2.46% real yield
- Settlement date: February 27, 2026
- Inflation index on settlement date: 0.99991 (slightly discounted from par)
- Coupon rate will be set to 1/8th percentage point below auctioned real yield (approximately 2.375%)
- Maturity date: February 15, 2056

**30-Year Real Yield Trends:**
- 30-year real yield down about 17 basis points since February 2, 2026
- Current rate of 2.46% is historically attractive
- In the last 16 years, only one TIPS auction (August 2025 reopening) generated a real yield this high
- Real yields have moved substantially higher since Federal Reserve ended quantitative easing in 2022

**Comparison Data:**
- 30-year Treasury bond closed Friday with nominal yield of 4.69%
- With real yield of 2.46%, the 30-year inflation breakeven rate would be 2.23%
- Inflation over the last 30 years (ending January 2026) has averaged 2.5%

**Historical Example:**
- A 30-year TIPS issued in February 2022 with 0.195% real yield is now trading at market price of about 55.05 (nearly 45% loss from original purchase price)

**January 2026 CPI Data:**
- Headline CPI increased 0.2% in January (less than expected 0.3%)
- Annual inflation: 2.4% (down from 2.7% in December), lowest since May 2025
- Core inflation: 0.3% monthly, 2.5% annually (down from 2.6% in December), lowest annual core rate since March 2021
- Non-seasonally adjusted CPI index: 325.252 (increase of 0.37% from December)

**TIPS Impact:**
- Principal balances for all TIPS will increase 0.37% in March (after falling 0.02% in February)

## Opinions from Named Source:

**Author David Enna (Tipswatch):**
- Considers this TIPS "most appropriate for an investor with an expectation to live through the maturity date of Feb. 15, 2056"
- Believes it would be "an excellent addition" to a 30-year ladder of TIPS investments for those who can hold to maturity
- Likes "the idea of having principal growing with inflation, while also collecting a coupon rate of nearly 2.5%"
- Recommends using a tax-deferred account due to long years to eventual payout
- Will not personally buy because his TIPS ladder extends only to 2043 (when he'll be 90)
- Advises buying TIPS with intention to hold to maturity, "even more important with a 30-year TIPS"

**Michael Ashton (referenced, from E-piphany site):**
- Article references his analysis of January CPI report but specific opinions not detailed in extracted content

## Additional Context:

- Auction closes Thursday at 1 p.m. EST
- Non-competitive bids at Treasury Direct must be placed by noon Thursday
- TIPS will outperform nominal bonds if inflation averages more than 2.23% over next 30 years
- 30-year bonds are highly volatile and will see significant value swings with interest rate changes
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFII30">
## Summary of Article

**Source:** FRED (Federal Reserve Economic Data), St. Louis Federal Reserve

**Key Information:**

1. **Data Series Details:**
   - Series ID: DFII30
   - Title: Market Yield on U.S. Treasury Securities at 30-Year Constant Maturity, Quoted on an Investment Basis, Inflation-Indexed
   - Units: Percent
   - Frequency: Daily
   - Seasonal Adjustment: Not Seasonally Adjusted
   - Data Source: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (US)
   - Release: H.15 Selected Interest Rates

2. **Methodology and Additional Information:**
   - The article references the H.15 Statistical Release notes and the Treasury Yield Curve Methodology for further information regarding treasury constant maturity data
   - Contact information is provided for data-related questions (directed to the data source) and FRED functionality questions

3. **Citation Information:**
   - Suggested citation format is provided for referencing this data series

**Note:** This article appears to be a standard FRED data series page with metadata and reference information. It does not contain specific data values, forecasts, expert opinions, or analysis that would be directly relevant to predicting the value on 2026-02-25. The content is primarily administrative and methodological in nature.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://home.treasury.gov/policy-issues/financing-the-government/interest-rate-statistics">
## Summary of Article: Interest Rate Statistics (U.S. Department of the Treasury, December 23, 2025)

### Key Facts and Information:

**Data Sources and Methodology:**
- The par yield curve is based on closing market bid prices on the most recently auctioned Treasury securities in the over-the-counter market
- Input market prices are indicative quotations obtained by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York at approximately 3:30 PM each business day
- The Treasury Yield Curve Methodology page provides detailed information on how the yield curve is derived

**Treasury Inflation Protected Securities (TIPS) - Par Real Curve:**
- The par real curve relates the par real yield on TIPS to its time to maturity
- Based on closing market bid prices on the most recently auctioned TIPS in the over-the-counter market
- Par real yields are derived from input market prices obtained by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York at approximately 3:30 PM each business day
- Treasury began publishing this series on January 2, 2004, with 1 year of historical data released at that time

**Historical Note on 30-Year Rates:**
- Treasury ceased publication of the 30-year constant maturity series on February 18, 2002
- Resumed the 30-year series on February 9, 2006
- During the gap period, the series used the Treasury 20-year Constant Maturity rate plus an "adjustment factor" to estimate a 30-year rate

**Long-Term Real Rate Average:**
- Beginning January 2, 2004, Treasury began publishing a Long-Term Real Rate Average
- Intended for use as a proxy for long-term real rates
- Treasury provides historical data back to 2000

**Note:** This article provides general background information about Treasury interest rate statistics and methodologies but does not contain specific forecasts or current values for the DFII30 series relevant to the February 25, 2026 date in question.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.scotsmanguide.com/news/will-a-fed-rate-cut-lower-mortgage-rates/">
# Summary of Article: "A Fed rate cut is imminent. But will it lower mortgage rates?"

**Source:** Scotsman Guide  
**Date:** September 16, 2025  
**Author:** Ryan Kingsley

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Current federal funds rate range:** 4.25% to 4.5%
- **Expected Fed action:** 25-basis-point cut (96% of futures traders predict this as of Tuesday afternoon; only 4% predict a 50-basis-point cut; 0% expect rates to hold steady, per CME Fed Watch tool)
- **Inflation rate:** 2.9% annually in August (based on consumer price index data)
- **Fed's inflation target:** 2% over the long run
- **Unemployment benchmark:** 4% is often used as a general benchmark for maximum employment

## Named Expert Opinions:

**Mark Zandi (Chief Economist, Moody's Analytics):**
- Would vote for a 25-basis-point rate cut if on the FOMC
- Believes economic recession risks are "very high" with warning signals from stalled job creation
- States inflation expectations remain "well tethered at least in the bond market"
- Expects tariff-driven price hikes will not prove persistent
- Goal should be ensuring recent inflation upticks don't become entrenched over next 6-12 months

**Doug Duncan (Former Senior Vice President and Chief Economist at Fannie Mae):**
- Does not believe the U.S. is on the cusp of recession
- Attributes job creation prospects to businesses' need for certainty more than a small rate cut
- Anticipates mortgage rates closer to 5.5% through 2026 if risk premiums related to debt and inflation disappear, or closer to 6.5% if those pressures persist
- Notes tariffs have contributed increased risk premiums to interest rates due to uncertainty
- States "The Fed's tools have a greater ability to address inflation than employment"

**Preetam Purohit (Head of Hedging and Analytics at Embrace Home Loans):**
- Cites rising initial unemployment claims, high continuous claims, and back-to-back downbeat nonfarm payroll reports as evidence the job market is weakening
- Identifies the surprise factor as how federal courts rule on Trump administration's global tariffs

**Lisa Sturtevant (Chief Economist, Bright MLS):**
- Believes mortgage rates have already baked in some of the expected Fed rate cut
- Warns: "We should not expect rates to drop much further"
- Notes possibility that mortgage rates could actually increase after the Fed cut if investors worry the Fed has taken their eye off inflation

**Selma Hepp (Chief Economist, Cotality):**
- Expects the Fed may take a more cautious approach to additional rate cuts in upcoming meetings
- Predicts "slow and painful improvement in the housing market" continuing through 2026 due to more inventory and affordability improvements

**Erica Groshen (Former BLS Commissioner, 2013-2017):**
- Notes survey response rates have fallen by more than half since 2015
- Warns that funding and staffing cuts by the Trump administration compound data quality problems
- Cautions: "Lousy data would give you lousy decisions, so the Fed could overreact or underreact to current economic conditions"

## Additional Context:

- President Trump has waged a "divisive rate-cut pressure campaign" for months, calling for the benchmark federal funds rate to be set between 0.25% and 1.75%
- Trump fired BLS Commissioner Erika McEntarfer following a poor July jobs report and hefty revisions to May and June employment estimates
- Mortgage rates take their cue from Treasury bond yields; the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is benchmarked to the 10-year Treasury note
- The article notes bond prices and yields have an inverse relationship
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/04/us-treasury-yields-investors-look-ahead-to-further-economic-data-.html">
## Summary of Article: Treasury yields are little changed after weaker-than-expected January hiring report

**Date:** February 04, 2026  
**Source:** CNBC  
**Authors:** Sean Conlon, Sawdah Bhaimiya

### Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Treasury Yields (as of February 4, 2026):**
  - 10-year Treasury yield: rose less than 1 basis point to 4.276%
  - 30-year Treasury yield: gained more than 1 basis point to 4.917%
  - 2-year Treasury note yield: down more than 1 basis point at 3.559%

- **Employment Data:**
  - Private companies added only 22,000 positions in January 2026 (ADP report)
  - December 2025 figure was downwardly revised to 37,000 (from a higher previous estimate)
  - Job market characterized as "low-hire, low-fire environment"

### Named Source Opinions:

- **Bret Kenwell, eToro U.S. investment analyst:**
  - "Today's update serves as a reminder that the U.S. remains far from a robust jobs market"
  - "The ADP report alone won't be enough to sway Fed policymakers or alter interest rate expectations — nor should it. But if the January jobs report shows a similar dynamic, it should at a minimum help keep the Fed from adopting an overly restrictive stance as the first quarter progresses"

### Additional Context:

- The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) nonfarm payrolls report was delayed due to a partial government shutdown
- President Trump signed a bill ending the shutdown on Tuesday (February 3, 2026)
- The BLS January jobs report was rescheduled for release on Wednesday, February 11, 2026
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/trading-investing/bond-market-outlook">
# Summary of Fidelity Bond Market Outlook 2026 Article

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Bloomberg US Aggregate Bond Index**: Returned approximately 7% for 2025 as of late November
- **Federal Reserve rate cuts**: The Fed has cut its benchmark interest rate by nearly 2 percentage points over the past year and a half
- **Last DFII30 data point mentioned in question background**: 2.48% as of 2026-02-12

## Expert Opinions from Named Sources:

**Robin Foley** (Head of Fixed Income at Fidelity):
- "Fixed income remains a valuable choice in a diversified portfolio, especially if investors seek liquidity and risk-adjusted returns"

**Dirk Hofschire** (Managing Director of Research, Fidelity's Asset Allocation Research Team):
- US Treasury rates are now approximately at "fair value" and could present an attractive entry point
- Relatively high starting yields can add to bonds' total returns and help provide a cushion against interest rate volatility

**Jake Weinstein** (Senior Vice President, Fidelity's AART):
- Expectations for future economic growth and inflation are typically most important in driving intermediate- and long-term bond rates
- "If the US sees a growth boom or if inflation remains sticky, longer-term interest rates could go higher"

**David De Biase** (Co-manager, Fidelity Intermediate Bond Fund):
- A well-constructed actively managed portfolio of bonds with intermediate maturities may offer potential for capital appreciation and inflation-beating returns in the year ahead

**Michael Plage** (Co-manager, Fidelity Investment Grade Bond Fund and Total Bond Fund):
- "The all-important starting yields are still relatively high and the Federal Reserve is expected to continue reducing interest rates"
- Describes this as "the combination I've been waiting for"

**Beau Coash** (Institutional Portfolio Manager):
- "I still believe bonds can help provide portfolio stability and may help mitigate risks during extreme stock market downturns"
- Expects the inverse-correlation benefit of owning bonds to hold up in most scenarios, with exceptions for extreme inflation pickups or if rates rise to compensate for higher government debt issuance

## Key Market Dynamics Discussed:

1. **Term premium**: After a period where short-term bonds yielded more than long-term ones, the return of the term premium (additional yield for longer lending periods) helped fuel bond price volatility in 2025

2. **Interest rate outlook**: The market generally expects further Fed rate cuts could be on the table, which could bring down short-term rates

3. **Government debt concerns**: Growing US federal debt burden may impact the bond market through increased supply of government bonds, potentially driving yields up and prices down

4. **Fed independence question**: Speculation about whether the Fed might need to cut rates to help the government afford its debts, which could stoke inflation fears

**Note**: The article appears to be cut off mid-sentence at the end of the extracted content.
</Summary>

<Asknews_articles>
Query: What will be the value of "Market Yield on U.S. Treasury Securities at 30-Year Constant Maturity, Quoted on an Investment Basis, Inflation-Indexed" on 2026-02-25?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Bonds open steady, traders await fresh cues**
Government bond yields remained steady at the opening on February 17, 2026, pausing a recent upward trend, as traders awaited further signals amid concerns over bond market supply. The 10-year benchmark bond yield was at 6.6693 percent, slightly up from 6.666 percent in the previous session. Investors remained cautious due to a supply glut, despite recent bond price gains driven by the government's debt switch from 2027 to 2040 bonds. Traders expect yields to remain elevated, as the government anticipates significant gross issuance in the next fiscal year, raising concerns that demand may not match supply. A softer-than-expected inflation print in January—within the Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) mandated band under the 2024 framework—prevented an upward bias in treasury yields. According to Finrex Treasury Advisors, 'The government switch of bonds from 2027 to 2040 has allowed bond prices to gain and a softish inflation data. Investors eye upcoming auctions and RBI liquidity amid a steady policy stance.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2026 04:34 AM
Source:[MoneyControl](https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/markets/bonds-open-steady-traders-await-fresh-cues-13831319.html)

**US 10-Year Yield Hits 2½-Month Low | Forex News 2026.02.17 (en)**
The yield on the US 10-year Treasury note declined toward 4%, reaching its lowest level since early December 2025, following last week's soft inflation data that reinforced expectations of Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. Markets now anticipate a potential rate cut in June, pricing in approximately 62 basis points of easing for 2026—equivalent to two quarter-point reductions and a roughly 50% probability of a third cut. Despite this, stronger-than-expected payroll growth—the largest increase in over a year—and an unexpected drop in the unemployment rate indicated continued strength in the labor market. Investors are now awaiting the Federal Reserve's recent meeting minutes, advance GDP data, and the core Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) price index—the Fed’s preferred inflation measure—for further signals on monetary policy. US bond markets were closed on Monday, February 17, 2026, in observance of Presidents' Day.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2026 03:10 AM
Source:[InstaForex](https://www.instaforex.com/forex-news/2893593)

**Bond Market Anticipates Two Fed Rate Cuts in 2026, Outperforming Equities**
The global investment-grade bond market has priced in two interest rate cuts by the U.S. Federal Reserve for 2026, ahead of the Fed's official guidance, driven by weaker-than-expected U.S. inflation data in January. The Bloomberg Global Aggregate Index for investment-grade bonds rose to 510 points, its highest level since March 2022, reflecting strong buying pressure. U.S. 10-year Treasury yields fell to 4.05%, nearly 30 basis points below their 2026 peak in mid-January, while German bunds dropped to 2.76% and Spanish 10-year bonds fell below 3.2%. Shorter-duration U.S. bonds saw the largest price increases and yield declines, with 12-month U.S. debt at 3.43%—its lowest level since July 2022. This shift is attributed to a dovish market outlook, reduced risk appetite, and strong demand for corporate bonds, particularly from tech giants like Alphabet, which raised $20 billion with a bond offering attracting over €100 billion in demand. The market also reacted to expectations that Kevin Warsh, the likely successor to Jerome Powell, may accelerate monetary easing. As of February 16, 2026, a diversified investment-grade bond portfolio would yield 1.7% annually, outperforming the German DAX and S&P 500, which are projected to deliver losses for European investors. According to TD Securities’ Molly Brooks, the bond rally reflects declining risk perception, while Nomura’s Jonathan Cohn noted that recent economic data alone cannot fully explain the rally, underscoring the role of risk-off behavior.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 16, 2026 06:00 PM
Source:[elEconomista.es](https://www.eleconomista.es/mercados-cotizaciones/noticias/13778845/02/26/el-mercado-de-bonos-se-adelanta-a-la-fed-y-descuenta-dos-recortes-de-tipos-de-interes-para-2026.html)

**BTp Yield Holds at 3.37%, Spread with Bund Stabilizes at 61 Basis Points**
The Italian 10-year government bond (BTp) closed unchanged at a yield of 3.37%, matching Friday's closing level, according to Il Sole 24 Ore. This reflects a continued slowdown in medium- to long-term bond yields across the Eurozone and U.S. Treasury markets during the first half of February 2026. The spread between the Italian BTp and the German Bund with the same maturity stood at 61 basis points at the end of trading, aligning with Friday's figure. Market activity was limited due to reduced participation from American investors, who were absent because of the U.S. Presidents' Day holiday.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 16, 2026 05:18 PM
Source:[Il Sole 24 ORE](https://www.ilsole24ore.com/radiocor/nRC_16.02.2026_17.49_41910419)

**U.S. Treasury Bonds: Is Now the Time to Buy or Sell?**
The article analyzes the current state of U.S. Treasury bonds amid uncertainty over Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. It notes that the 10-year Treasury yield has dropped sharply from a high of 4.28%-4.29% to around 4.05%, approaching a key psychological and technical threshold near 3.94%, which could signal a shift from weakness to potential strengthening in bond prices. Inflation data from January 2026 shows a slowdown, with headline inflation at 2.4% annually—down from 2.7% in December—driven by a 7.5% year-on-year drop in fuel prices and a 2% decline in used car prices. However, energy costs rose significantly (+9.8% for gas, +6.3% for electricity), and food prices increased by 2.9%, while airline fares surged 6.5% monthly. Despite these mixed signals, markets remain divided on the likelihood of Fed rate cuts. Futures data suggest only two or at most three rate cuts are priced in, less than what some political figures like Trump advocate. The article concludes that while long-term Treasuries may rise in value, holding them carries significant risk. As a result, the prevailing market advice is to favor short- and medium-term Treasuries (up to three years) and to hedge exposure via U.S. dollar-denominated accounts, as these low-duration bonds currently offer a 3.5% yield—deemed substantial amid ongoing uncertainty.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 16, 2026 01:29 PM
Source:[Money.it](https://www.money.it/bond-oggi-treasuries-usa-e-il-momento-di-vendere-o-di-comprare)

**Indian bonds rise on U.S. Treasury rally, ample cash**
Indian government bonds rose on February 16, 2026, driven by a rally in U.S. Treasuries and abundant domestic liquidity, though concerns over bond supply limited gains. The benchmark 6.48% 2035 bond yield fell to 6.6642%, down from 6.6799% the previous Friday. Longer-duration bonds saw the largest yield declines: the 15-year yield dropped by approximately 4 basis points to 7.068%, and the 40-year bond yield fell 4.5 bps to 7.4520%. Despite a 100-basis-point interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in fiscal year 2025-26, yields on 15- to 40-year bonds have risen 40–50 basis points due to weak demand from insurers and pension funds and rising supply concerns. Traders noted that current yield levels are attractive for re-entry, especially after a debt switch operation by New Delhi reduced near-term supply and surplus liquidity returned, with average daily system liquidity at 2.62 trillion rupees in February, compared to 660 billion rupees in January. Alok Singh, head of treasury at CSB Bank, stated, 'RBI liquidity support is necessary for yields to sustain at lower levels,' adding, 'If liquidity stays in surplus, supply won't be a challenge.' Indian overnight index swap (OIS) rates also declined, tracking U.S. Treasury movements: the one-year OIS rate fell 1.25 bps to 5.49%, the two-year rate dropped 2.25 bps to 5.5950%, and the five-year rate declined 4 bps to 6.0250%. U.S. 10-year Treasury yields fell about 15 bps to multi-month lows near 4.05% on Friday, following a U.S. retail inflation report showing a 0.2% rise in January, down from 0.3% in December.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 12:40 PM
Source:[Economic Times](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/bonds/indian-bonds-rise-on-u-s-treasury-rally-ample-cash/articleshow/128422996.cms)

**U.S. Treasury Yields Near 4.05%: Why No One Is Buying Yet?**
On February 16, 2026, U.S. 10-year Treasury yields fell to 4.051%, nearing the 240-minute Bollinger Band lower band at 4.046%, indicating a technically oversold condition but lacking clear stabilization signals. The yield decline since February 5 has been driven by holiday effects and a rebound in the U.S. dollar, which rose to 96.9589, retesting the 240-minute Bollinger Band middle band. The dollar's strength increases the currency cost for non-U.S. investors holding U.S. bonds, suppressing cross-border demand, especially with Asian investors absent due to the Lunar New Year holiday. Meanwhile, Federal Reserve officials signaled potential rate cuts, but highlighted persistent service sector inflation, leaving the March 18 meeting path uncertain. The market has largely priced in a hold, but further yield declines require stronger dovish signals. Technically, the 10-year yield remains below the 50-day moving average (4.184%) and MACD shows slight negative momentum contraction, suggesting limited upside for now. In contrast, gold has stabilized around $5,024.67, with MACD showing reduced negative momentum, and analysts have revised their medium-term target to $5,100–$5,200. A key insight is the negative convenience yield of U.S. Treasuries relative to German bonds over the past 15 years, indicating market perception of higher risk in holding U.S. debt. This reflects growing concerns about U.S. fiscal risk, including potential impacts from illegal tariff legislation that could reduce annual revenue by $100–$130 billion, further pressuring an already elevated fiscal deficit (5.8%–6.0%). With Asian markets still closed and U.S. markets resuming trading, yields are expected to oscillate between 4.046% and 4.136% in the near term. Key watchpoints include whether the dollar can sustain above 96.86 and test 97.10, and whether U.S. equity market strength draws capital from bonds. Despite underpricing of fiscal risk, short-term dynamics remain dominated by technical rebound attempts and low liquidity, with no trend reversal likely without a new catalyst.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 16, 2026 11:14 AM
Source:[和讯外汇](http://forex.hexun.com/2026-02-16/223498984.html)

**US 10-year Treasury yield eases as inflation softens | Investing.com ZA**
US headline inflation eased to 2.40% in January 2026, the lowest level since May 2025 and below the 2.50% forecast, leading the 10-year Treasury yield to decline to 4.07%. Economists attributed much of the slowdown to base effects from last year’s elevated readings. Markets now price in two additional interest rate cuts later in 2026. Equity futures recovered from early losses, but major indices closed mostly flat: the S&P 500 and Nasdaq were steady, while the Dow Jones lost 100 points, ending a 1.50% weekly decline amid ongoing artificial intelligence (AI) market volatility. Megacap tech and semiconductor stocks were pressured, with Nvidia down 2.20%, Apple 2.30%, Alphabet 1.10%, Meta 1.60%, and Broadcom 1.80%, while Oracle, Palantir, Microsoft, and Micron remained flat. In contrast, Salesforce rose 2.30%, and Applied Materials and Arista Networks surged 10% each on strong earnings, defying broader tech weakness. In energy, the US eased sanctions on Venezuela’s oil and gas sector via two general licenses, enabling international firms to operate and attract new capital—a significant shift since the removal of President Nicolás Maduro last month. Silver rose nearly 4% to $77.50 an ounce, recovering from Thursday’s losses, while gold advanced toward $5,020 an ounce, reducing weekly losses. European shares dipped slightly: the STOXX 50 fell 0.40% to 5,987, and the STOXX 600 declined 0.10% to 617, marking two consecutive days of modest declines after a record high. Banks including UniCredit, Deutsche Bank, and BBVA dropped 3.50% to 4%, L'Oréal fell 5% on weak year-end sales despite earnings, and Hermès dipped slightly despite beating profit forecasts; Safran surged 8.30% after raising its full-year outlook. Eurozone employment rose 0.30%, supporting expectations of stable European Central Bank (ECB) rates. In the UK, the FTSE 100 gained 0.30% after a 0.70% drop on Thursday, lifted by rebounds in AI-exposed and defence stocks—RELX jumped 9%, and London Stock Exchange Group rose over 0.50%. Germany’s DAX 40 rose 0.30%, ending a three-day decline on strength in defence, aerospace, and tech stocks. Asian markets closed mixed: Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index fell 0.90% to 27,032.54 amid pre-Lunar New Year light trading, with Lenovo down 4.60% and NetEase losing 4.10%; Alibaba Group edged 0.90% lower despite increasing its AI focus. Japan’s Nikkei 225 ended nearly unchanged at 57,639.84 after briefly surpassing 58,000. China’s Shanghai Composite rose 0.10% to 4,134.02. Locally, the South African rand weakened on Friday due to lower global commodity prices and stronger-than-expected US labor data, though early support emerged from precious metals. CNBC Africa noted that a sustained rebound in commodity prices could limit further rand depreciation. In political developments, President Cyril Ramaphosa announced plans to deploy the military to combat organized crime and to pursue legal action against municipal officials failing to deliver water services—this favorable policy response boosted investor confidence in the rand.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 06:45 AM
Source:[Investing.com South Africa](https://za.investing.com/analysis/us-10year-treasury-yield-eases-as-inflation-softens-200617362)

**India bonds steady as supply overhang caps Treasury-driven gains**
Indian government bonds traded in a narrow range on February 16, 2026, as lower U.S. Treasury yields provided support, but concerns over upcoming domestic debt supply limited gains. The 10-year benchmark 6.48% 2035 bond yield held steady at 6.6750% as of 10:55 a.m. IST, compared to 6.6799% on Friday, reflecting inverse movement between bond yields and prices. The 10-year U.S. Treasury yield dropped to a multi-month low of 4.05% on Friday, driven by a 0.2% January U.S. Consumer Price Index rise, below December’s 0.3%. Traders noted that while lower U.S. yields are positive, heavy domestic debt supply through March is expected to prevent a significant decline in Indian yields. The domestic 10-year yield eased about 6 basis points during the week, less than the 15 bps drop in U.S. yields, supported by a softer domestic inflation print and New Delhi’s bond switch. Market participants emphasized that additional support, such as buybacks, is needed to significantly reduce yields. Meanwhile, banking system liquidity surged, with the February average surplus at 2.62 trillion rupees, up from 660 billion rupees in January, which may help balance demand and supply, especially at shorter maturities. After the January-March quarter, liquidity is expected to ease, enhancing rate cut transmission in the money market. India’s overnight index swap (OIS) rates also declined: one-year OIS fell 1.75 bps to 5.4850%, two-year OIS dropped 3.25 bps to 5.5850%, and five-year OIS eased 3 bps to 6.0350%.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 06:14 AM
Source:[Economic Times](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/bonds/india-bonds-steady-as-supply-overhang-caps-treasury-driven-gains/articleshow/128408765.cms)

**China Experts Forecast Weak Dollar to Boost Asian and Emerging Market Bonds Amid Global Policy Divergence and Geopolitical Risks**
According to Chinese financial experts, a persistently weak U.S. dollar is expected to continue benefiting Asian and emerging market bonds, despite heightened risks from geopolitical tensions and divergent global monetary policies. The article highlights that U.S. Treasury yields have declined recently, with the 10-year yield falling to a two-month low of 4.05%, while the U.S. dollar index dipped to 96.91. This shift is attributed to several factors: concerns over Federal Reserve independence, political interference under a potential Trump administration, and European pension funds reducing U.S. Treasury holdings due to geopolitical disputes, such as the U.S. pursuit of Greenland. Additionally, Chinese regulators have reportedly instructed domestic banks to cap their U.S. Treasury holdings to manage risk, particularly amid fears that Kevin Warsh, a hawkish nominee for Fed Chair, could drive yields higher. Despite the U.S. economy showing strong job growth in January—130,000 new jobs versus an expected 65,000—market expectations for rate cuts remain intact, with analysts forecasting two cuts in 2026 and possibly three. The 2-year Treasury yield dropped to 3.408%, its lowest in four months. Meanwhile, emerging market U.S.-dollar high-yield bonds delivered a 13.9% return in 2025, outperforming U.S. government bonds, which returned only 0.2%. Experts like Zhang Haoen of CITIC Bank (International) and Ding Meng, chief economist at the same institution, emphasize that diversified bond portfolios—spanning investment-grade, floating-rate, inflation-protected, and short-duration bonds—are essential to mitigate concentration risk. They caution that single-market exposure increases vulnerability to shocks, especially with rising long-term yields in Japan due to fiscal concerns, though recent reassurances from Japanese Prime Minister Hatoyama have stabilized markets. Over the past six months, 32 new bond funds have been approved in Hong Kong, reflecting strong market activity ahead of the anticipated rate-cut cycle. Conversely, three bond funds have been delisted, including the Allianz Emerging Markets SR1 Bond Fund and others. The overarching advice remains: maintain diversified exposure across regions and asset classes to enhance long-term returns and resilience.

**Treasury Yield Trend Revived by Consumer Confidence Slump | Stock Market News**
A rally in short-maturity U.S. Treasuries, driven by a sharp decline in January's Conference Board consumer sentiment index to its lowest level in over a decade, revived the yield-curve steepening trend from 2025 that had stalled in early 2026. The drop in consumer confidence strengthened expectations of two Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts in 2026, prompting short-term Treasury yields to fall—most notably, the two-year note yield dropped more than three basis points from its daily high. For much of 2025, short-term yields declined due to anticipation of Fed rate cuts, while longer-term yields remained elevated due to inflation concerns and higher borrowing costs, resulting in record-wide yield differentials between two- and 10-year notes and between five- and 30-year notes. However, in early 2026, short-term yields rose amid signs of labor market strength, including a declining unemployment rate, narrowing yield spreads. Despite weak demand for the five-year note auction on Tuesday, the 30-year yield rose, widening the five- to 30-year spread by nearly four basis points—the largest one-day increase in 2026. At the first of eight Federal Reserve meetings in 2026, policymakers are expected to hold rates steady. Yet, interest rate swap contracts fully price in a rate cut by July and an additional cut by year-end.

Publish date: January 27, 2026 08:56 PM

**US bond market faces a more challenging road ahead in 2026**
US bond investors are expected to face a more challenging environment in 2026 after a stellar performance in 2025, driven by a 75 basis point cumulative Federal Reserve rate cut, a resilient economy, and strong corporate earnings. These factors boosted bond prices and kept credit risks low, resulting in broad bond indices posting over 7% total returns in 2025 — the best performance since 2020. The Morningstar US Core Bond Total Return Index gained more than 7%, while investment-grade bonds delivered nearly 8% returns, supported by credit spreads near multi-decade lows (around 80 basis points). However, expectations for 2026 are more muted: traders are pricing in only about 60 basis points of rate cuts, slower than in 2025. Fiscal stimulus measures, including potential tax and spending initiatives, could support growth and keep longer-term yields elevated. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields fell by over 40 basis points in 2025 to around 4.1%, but major banks forecast they will end 2026 at or slightly above current levels. A divergence may emerge, with shorter-maturity yields declining further while longer-term yields could rise due to stronger growth or higher government debt, pressuring long-duration bond returns. Asset managers are becoming cautious on duration, favoring shorter-dated securities. Credit spreads may widen in 2026 due to increased corporate borrowing, especially from large tech firms, potentially reducing returns for investment-grade and high-yield bonds. While some analysts expect a stronger bond rally if inflation eases and growth slows, requiring aggressive Fed cuts, the overall outlook points to steadier, harder-earned returns compared to the exceptional gains of 2025.

**Treasury Yields Hold Steady As Wall Street Braces For 'Considerably Slower' Q4 GDP**
U.S. Treasury yields remained relatively stable on Friday, December 26, 2025, with the 10-year yield falling one basis point to 4.132%, the 30-year yield rising one basis point to 4.801%, and the 2-year yield declining two basis points to 3.493%. Analysts at ING Think anticipate 'considerably slower' fourth-quarter GDP growth, citing the 43-day U.S. government shutdown and a projected slowdown in consumer spending. Despite expectations of muted growth, long-term yields did not collapse due to persistent macroeconomic caution, term-premium pressures, and structural market forces. Gregory Faranello of AmeriVet Securities noted that sustained inflation and growth make a significant drop in 10-year yields unlikely. Jeremy Siegel, professor emeritus at Wharton, expects further Federal Reserve rate cuts, potentially bringing rates to the low-3% range, but does not foresee a collapse in long-term yields, which he expects to remain anchored in the low-4% range due to term premium, issuance, and structural factors. Nuveen analysts believe Treasury entry points will become increasingly attractive, with duration likely to regain its role as a growth hedge, despite risks from tariffs impacting consumer spending and business investment. The iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond ETF (TLT) rose 0.15%, and the iShares 7-10 Year Treasury Bond ETF (IEF) gained 0.16%, with retail sentiment on TLT in 'bullish' territory. Upcoming data includes FOMC minutes from December, home sales data, the S&P Case-Shiller index, and the weekly jobless claims report.

**30-Year U.S. Treasuries: The Year’s Most Unexpected Asset Despite Volatility**
The 30-year U.S. Treasury bond emerged as one of the most 'miraculous' assets in global financial markets in 2025, defying expectations by maintaining near-constant prices despite a year of extreme volatility. While AI stocks surged and gold rose nearly 70%, the 30-year U.S. bond saw its yield remain stable at around 4.8%—unchanged from年初—outperforming comparable long-term bonds in Germany and Japan, which saw yields rise by over 100 basis points. Despite the Federal Reserve’s 75 basis point rate cuts, persistent high inflation limited downward pressure on long-term yields. The bond’s resilience is attributed to structural demand from retirement funds, insurance companies, and mutual funds seeking near-5% risk-free returns for asset-liability matching. The U.S. Treasury successfully conducted 12 auctions totaling $276 billion, with an average bid-to-cover ratio of 2.37—consistent with the past four years. Auction data revealed investors still demanded a term premium, and foreign holdings rebounded in the second half, reaching 15% in November—the highest since early 2024. However, the sustainability of this 'dancing on the edge' equilibrium remains uncertain due to ongoing inflation risks, debt supply pressures, policy credibility concerns, and the uncertain impact of AI-driven productivity. The 30-year U.S. Treasury’s stability in 2025 may itself be the most unrepeatable miracle.

**Surprise asset of the year? The 30-year U.S. Treasury bond**
The 30-year U.S. Treasury bond is being hailed as the financial asset of 2025, despite not experiencing price gains this year. While it has not matched the returns of AI stocks or gold, it has remained stable, with its yield around 4.8%—essentially unchanged from the start of the year—despite significant macroeconomic headwinds. These include persistently high inflation, a 10% decline in the U.S. dollar, a rise in the U.S. 'term premium' to its highest level in over a decade, attacks on Federal Reserve independence by the Trump administration, and the upcoming 'One Big Beautiful Bill' that could add trillions to the budget deficit. Despite these pressures, the bond's yield has not risen significantly. The 10-year yield has fallen nearly 50 basis points due to Fed rate cuts, but longer-dated yields have been constrained by inflation above target. The 2s/30s yield curve has steepened to its steepest level in four years, though this is driven by front-end movements. Internationally, Germany’s 30-year bund yield rose nearly 100 bps and Japan’s 30-year bond yield reached an all-time high. The U.S. bond’s resilience is attributed to strong demand from 'real money' investors—pension funds, mutual funds, and insurance companies—seeking long-duration assets to match liabilities. Treasury’s 12 auctions in 2025 were successful, with an average bid-to-cover ratio of 2.37, close to the 50-auction average of 2.38 since November 2021. Domestic institutional investors held 70–75% of the bonds, and foreign demand increased in the second half of the year, reaching over 15% in November—the highest since early 2024. Investors generally paid higher yields than pre-sale market levels, indicating strong demand. However, challenges for 2026 are expected to be more severe, with rising risk premia, inflation risks, higher debt supply, doubts about AI productivity, and continued threats to Fed independence, all of which could test the bond’s resilience.

**U.S. Treasury’s Safe-Haven Glow Reawakened by Credit Storm: '4% Zone' in Focus**
The U.S. Treasury market has shown renewed strength amid renewed risk-off sentiment, with benchmark yields falling to multi-month lows. The 2-year Treasury yield dropped below 3.4%—the lowest since 2022—while the 10-year yield saw its largest weekly decline in four months, briefly falling below 4% before rebounding above it by Friday. This followed a prior surge in bond demand triggered by escalating trade tensions earlier in the month. The recent rally was driven by investor panic over regional banking credit risks and a government shutdown that delayed key economic data, including September CPI. Market participants, including JPMorgan Asset Management’s Priya Misra, view U.S. Treasuries as an ideal hedge, with her firm holding 5- to 10-year notes to gain confidence in credit investments. With weakening labor market signals, traders now expect a 25-basis-point rate cut by the Fed by month-end. Despite high equity and credit valuations, 10-year yields near 4% are seen as a safe haven. Even 30-year bonds rose, partially offsetting concerns over global 'currency depreciation trades,' though massive borrowing needs continue to support gold prices above $4,000 per ounce. The recent bond surge recalls the 2023 Silicon Valley Bank crisis, when 2-year yields dropped over 100 basis points. Traders are now closely watching the 4% threshold on the 10-year yield, with the yield briefly hitting 3.93%—its lowest since April 7—before rebounding. Options markets indicate bets on further declines below 4%, which could trigger additional hedging and amplify gains. The Bloomberg U.S. Treasury Index has risen 6.6% year-to-date, potentially making 2025 the best year for bonds since 2020. Morgan Stanley’s Matthew Hornbach argues that 10-year yields above 4% are nearing their end, citing prolonged government shutdown risks. However, upcoming economic data, particularly the delayed September CPI (now due October 24), may temporarily halt further declines. Economists expect core CPI to remain at 0.3% monthly, keeping year-over-year inflation at 3.1%, well above the Fed’s 2% target. AmeriVet Securities’ Gregory Faranello stated that while the 10-year yield has room to fall below 4%, conditions would need to deteriorate significantly.

**Personal Finance: Safe Investments During Crises | Low Risk | The Epoch Times**
The article, published on October 11, 2025, by The Epoch Times, discusses safe investment options during economic crises. It highlights several low-risk investment vehicles: U.S. Treasury Bonds (T-bonds), which are long-term government securities (20–30 years) with semi-annual interest payments and federal tax on interest, but exempt from state and local taxes; Treasury Notes (T-notes), with maturities of 2, 3, 5, 7, or 10 years, also paying interest semi-annually and taxed similarly; Treasury Bills (T-bills), short-term loans (one year or less) purchased at a discount, with profit derived from the difference between purchase price and face value; and Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS), whose principal adjusts with inflation (measured by CPI), providing protection against rising prices, with maturities of 5, 10, or 30 years. The article also recommends defensive stocks and funds in sectors like consumer staples, utilities, and healthcare, which provide essential goods and services regardless of economic conditions, as well as dividend-paying stocks and funds for stable income. Cash equivalents such as high-yield savings accounts, money market accounts (insured up to $250,000), and certificates of deposit (CDs) with fixed rates and federal insurance are advised, though early withdrawal from CDs incurs penalties. The article concludes that, despite economic downturns, multiple secure investment avenues exist, including government securities, defensive equities, and insured cash accounts. The content is presented as general informational guidance and does not constitute financial advice.

**Treasury Yield 30 Years Index: A Step-by-Step Progress**
The yield on 30-year U.S. Treasury bonds rose sharply to 4.762% on October 6, 2025, an increase of 5.2 basis points from Friday’s close. Despite the ongoing U.S. government shutdown since October 1, 2024, long-term yields have shown surprising resilience. Typically considered safe-haven assets, Treasuries are seeing upward pressure due to market concerns over the shutdown. Investors are also awaiting the Federal Reserve’s meeting minutes later in the week for clues on the pace of potential interest rate cuts. Technically, the 30-year yield is testing resistance levels at 4.77% (1-week high) and 4.792% (1-year high), with an RSI of 44.59 indicating no overbought condition. The breakout above the double-top neckline at 4.712% signals further upside potential. A critical test comes on Thursday when the U.S. Department of the Treasury auctions $22 billion in bonds, which will gauge market demand. Meanwhile, equity markets show mixed signals: the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose 0.3% and 0.6%, respectively, while the Dow Jones fell 0.2%. The U.S. Dollar Index gained 0.4% to 98.13. Notably, both gold and oil rose—gold up 1.7% to a record high of approximately $3,980 and oil up 1.5% to $61.75—suggesting investors are simultaneously seeking safety and hedging against inflation. The latest Treasury Yield 30 Years Index analysis from October 6, 2025, urges immediate action, posing the question: should investors buy or sell?
